definition: A pattern of inflammatory skin disease where the principal inflammatory action occurs along the dermal-epidermal junction, resulting in obscuration of the junction, vacuolar change, and/or lichenoid infiltrates.
clinical: Clinical presentation varies widely depending on the specific disease entity (e.g., papules, plaques, targetoid lesions).
pathogenesis: Lymphocytes attack keratinocytes in the basal layer, injuring or killing them. Over time, this may alter epidermal maturation (squamatization).
microscopic: Lymphocytes on both sides of the junction obscuring the basement membrane. Presence of apoptotic/dyskeratotic keratinocytes (colloid bodies). 'Squamatization' of the basal layer (cells become flat/squamous rather than cuboidal). Can be classified into Vacuolar vs. Lichenoid, or by epidermal changes (Acute cytotoxic, Premature differentiation, Irregular hyperplasia, Psoriasiform hyperplasia, Atrophy).
differential_diagnosis: Spongiotic dermatitis (differentiation: if spongiosis extends to upper epidermis = spongiotic; if limited to lower epidermis with necrotic keratinocytes = interface; mixed = drug eruption/DRESS).

related_figures.legend: High power showing lymphocytes on both sides of the junction, apoptotic keratinocytes, and squamatization of the basal layer. (Time: 480s)
Mixed pattern showing lymphocytes around the superficial plexus, focal spongiosis, and vacuolar change. (Time: 761s)

entity_name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
definition: A severe adverse drug reaction characterized by a mixed pattern of spongiotic and interface dermatitis.
clinical: Systemic symptoms associated with drug eruption.
microscopic: Mixed pattern: Well-developed spongiosis combined with interface change (vacuolar alteration and dyskeratotic cells/necrotic keratinocytes).

related_figures.legend: Mixed pattern with well-developed spongiosis and vacuolar interface change. (Time: 882s)
Characteristic mixed pattern of spongiosis and interface dermatitis. (Time: 907s)

definition: An acute cytotoxic interface dermatitis characterized by targetoid lesions.
pathogenesis: Acute cytotoxic attack by lymphocytes on basal keratinocytes; eruption often recedes before epidermal metabolism/differentiation is altered.
microscopic: Lymphocytes at superficial plexus (usually not a dense band). Lymphocytes ascend to junction causing vacuolar change and keratinocyte necrosis (apoptosis). Apoptotic cells may group into 'world keratinocytic processes'. Normal basket-weave orthokeratosis (acute nature). Thin granular layer retained.
differential_diagnosis: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN) - EM usually has more lymphocytes and less full-thickness necrosis; biopsy edge of TEN may look like EM.

related_figures.legend: Targetoid clinical lesions. (Time: 1085s)
High power showing acute process with basket-weave cornified layer, thin granular layer, and apoptotic keratinocytes. (Time: 1124s)
Comparison of lymphocyte density; EM generally has more lymphocytes than TEN. (Time: 1454s)

definition: A severe acute cytotoxic interface dermatitis resulting in full-thickness epidermal necrosis.
clinical: Widespread detachment of epidermis. Targetoid lesions with dusky centers.
microscopic: Early: Vacuoles and dyskeratotic cells (similar to EM). Late/Established: Full-thickness epidermal necrosis. Sparse lymphocytic infiltrate (fewer lymphocytes than EM).
differential_diagnosis: Erythema Multiforme (biopsy of the edge of a TEN lesion may resemble EM; center shows necrosis).

related_figures.legend: Early changes with vacuoles and dyskeratotic cells around a vellus follicle. (Time: 1197s)
Comparison of sparse inflammation in TEN vs EM. (Time: 1203s)
Full thickness epidermal necrosis with sparse lymphocytes. (Time: 1488s)

definition: An acute cytotoxic interface dermatitis that recurs at the same site upon re-exposure to the offending drug.
microscopic: Lymphocytes at junction extending into spinous layer (higher than EM/TEN). Necrotic keratinocytes. **Eosinophils** often present. Prominent **Melanophages** (deep in dermis in recurrent lesions).
differential_diagnosis: Erythema Multiforme (FDE has more eosinophils and melanophages).

related_figures.legend: Clinical appearance of a round, dusky lesion. (Time: 1490s)
Interface dermatitis with lymphocytes, necrotic keratinocytes, eosinophils, and melanophages. (Time: 1545s)

definition: An acute cytotoxic interface dermatitis also known as Mucha-Habermann disease.
macroscopic: Variable papules with scale or crust.
microscopic: Lymphocytes killing keratinocytes at junction and above. **Parakeratosis with neutrophils** (distinct from other acute cytotoxic entities). Extravasated erythrocytes. Involvement of the deep vascular plexus. Wedge-shaped profile.
differential_diagnosis: Early lesions may mimic Erythema Multiforme or Drug Eruption (biopsy edge vs center).

related_figures.legend: Low power showing wedge shape, scale/crust, and hemorrhage. (Time: 1691s)
High power showing necrotic keratinocytes, parakeratosis with neutrophils, and extravasated RBCs. (Time: 1740s)

definition: An acute cytotoxic interface reaction occurring post-transplant.
microscopic: Vacuolar interface change. **Satellite cell necrosis** (lymphocytes adjacent to apoptotic keratinocytes). Follicular involvement (inflammation/necrosis around vellus follicles). Epidermal dysmaturation (atypical keratinocytes) may be present due to chemotherapy.
differential_diagnosis: Drug eruption, Viral exanthem, Erythema Multiforme (histologically similar; follicular accentuation is a soft clue for GVHD).

related_figures.legend: Vacuolar interface change, consistent with GVHD but non-specific. (Time: 1865s)
Dyskeratotic cells/necrosis accentuated around a vellus follicle. (Time: 1925s)

definition: The prototype of interface dermatitis with premature differentiation.
pathogenesis: T-cell attack on Alpha-6 Beta-4 integrin in basal layer, signaling premature terminal differentiation to create a barrier.
microscopic: Interface dermatitis with 'squamatization' of the basal layer (cells become flat). Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate. Wedge-shaped **hypergranulosis**. Compact **hyperkeratosis**. 'Saw-toothed' (pointed) rete ridges. Civatte/Colloid bodies (dyskeratotic cells dropping into dermis).

related_figures.legend: Demonstration of premature differentiation (hypergranulosis/compact hyperkeratosis) caused by trauma, analogous to LP mechanism. (Time: 2046s)
Hypergranulosis, compact hyperkeratosis, and band-like infiltrate. (Time: 2153s)
Squamatization of basal layer and colloid bodies. (Time: 2174s)

definition: A drug-induced interface dermatitis mimicking Lichen Planus but often with subtle histologic differences.
microscopic: Similar to Lichen Planus (band-like infiltrate, interface change) but often includes: **Eosinophils**, Plasma cells, Neutrophils. **Parakeratosis** (rare in idiopathic LP). Deep vascular plexus involvement. **Note:** Lichenoid photodermatitis looks more like true LP than generalized lichenoid drug eruption.

related_figures.legend: Lichenoid infiltrate with parakeratosis and deep plexus involvement. (Time: 2205s)
Presence of eosinophils and melanophages within the infiltrate. (Time: 2228s)

definition: A form of interface dermatitis characterized by irregular epidermal hyperplasia, often mimicking malignancy.
microscopic: Interface dermatitis with irregular epidermal hyperplasia (thickened, papillated). Ridges are jagged/pointed. Hyperkeratosis. Deep lymphocytic infiltrate (often periadnexal). Can mimic Squamous Cell Carcinoma (pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia).
differential_diagnosis: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (hypertrophic LE can be misdiagnosed as SCC; deep biopsy required to see architecture/deep infiltrate).

related_figures.legend: Thickened epidermis with irregular hyperplasia on the leg. (Time: 2323s)
Papillated, hyperkeratotic epidermis mimicking a verrucous keratosis. (Time: 2385s)

definition: An interface dermatitis that presents initially with psoriasiform hyperplasia before progressing to atrophy.
clinical: White atrophic plaques (late); early lesions may differ.
microscopic: Early/Edge: Interface dermatitis with **psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia** (evenly elongated, rounded ridges). Vacuolar change. Late/Center: Epidermal atrophy, sclerosis/homogenization of papillary dermis.
differential_diagnosis: Mycosis Fungoides (early LS&A can mimic MF due to psoriasiform hyperplasia and interface change).

related_figures.legend: Classic pallor/sclerosis on left; psoriasiform hyperplasia at the edge on the right. (Time: 2516s)
Smooth-based, psoriasiform ridges with vacuolar change. (Time: 2533s)

definition: A variant of lichen planus characterized by epidermal atrophy rather than hyperplasia.
clinical: Pigmented patches/macules (e.g., axilla). Overlap with Lichen Planus Pigmentosus.
pathogenesis: Long-standing interface attack whittling away rete ridges.
microscopic: Interface dermatitis with epidermal atrophy (thin epidermis, loss of ridges). Vacuolar change/clefting. Prominent melanophages (pigment incontinence).

related_figures.legend: Thin epidermis, loss of ridges, vacuolar change, and melanophages. (Time: 2581s)

definition: A connective tissue disease showing interface dermatitis with epidermal atrophy and mucin deposition.
microscopic: Interface dermatitis with epidermal atrophy (thinning, loss of ridges). Dyskeratotic cells at junction. **Mucin** deposition in the dermis.
differential_diagnosis: Lupus Erythematosus (histologically indistinguishable in many cases; both show atrophy + mucin).

related_figures.legend: Thin epidermis with loss of ridges and dermal inflammation. (Time: 2624s)
Dyskeratotic cells at junction and mucin in the dermis. (Time: 2642s)
